elements.content: The possibility to construct extended hybrid hydrogen-bonded networks by association of an anionic coordination complex and organic cations acting respectively as a hydrogen-bond acceptor and hydrogen-bond donors is explored. A series of seven architectures developed by charge-assisted hydrogen-bond association of {Zr(C2O4)4}4- (C2O4 = oxalate) and dications bearing N−H donor functions are described. The selected organic modules (i.e., protonated 4,4‘-bipyridine, di(4-pyridyl)ethane, di(4-pyridyl)ethylene, piperazine, m/p-phenylenediamine, terephtalamidine) possess two hydrogen-donor functions to allow them to act as bridges between the inorganic anions. Depending on the nature of the donor group, the number of hydrogens available for bonding, the geometric features, and sizes of the organic modules diverse assembling patterns have been observed ranging from one-dimensional (1-D) to three-dimensional (3-D) interlocked networks. A further, rather surprising hybrid system was realized by assembling the inorganic anion with 4,4‘-bypiridine-N,N‘-dioxide in acidic medium. For the latter, H3O+ and H+ act as actual linkers between the molecular units. The crystal structures for all eight supramolecular architectures as well as their thermal stabilities are reported.

elements.content: A series of hybrid architectures developed by charge-assisted hydrogen-bond association of the inorganic {Zr(C2O4)4}4- anion and dications bearing N−H donor functions are described. Depending on the nature of the donor group, the geometric features, and sizes of the organic modules diverse assembling patterns have been observed ranging from one-dimensional (1-D) to three-dimensional (3-D) interlocked networks. Bipyridine-oxide generated a 3-D network that contains H3O+ and H+ units stabilized by hydrogen-bonds with the framework.

elements.content: The design of molecule-based extended frameworks with functional properties has become an extremely active field of investigation. Materials with a wide variety of physical or chemical properties, such as optical, electric, magnetic, catalytic, zeolitic properties, or even combining two or more remarkable features, can be rationally prepared from appropriate building units, that is, molecules. The metal−ligand assemblage is a widely used tool, and numerous material-directed coordination polymers have been reported. Alternatively, the hydrogen bond represents the most suitable linkage for purely organic networks, but it also appears often as a secondary bonding scheme in metal−organic frameworks. The hydrogen linkage offers also the possibility to construct two-component hydride architectures by assembling preformed coordination compounds with organic modules. Such hybrid architectures are seldom envisaged for material-directed design but could combine the advantages of both inorganic (i.e., geometry, rigidity, physical property) and organic (i.e., shape and structural versatility, flexibility) components.

elements.content: In a recent work, we have used preformed {M(C2O4)4}4- building units (M = ZrIV, UIV; C2O4 2- = oxalate) in association with M2+ metal ions to prepare supramolecular nanoporous architectures. The three-dimensional (3-D) heterometallic frameworks are realized through the linkages between the outer oxygen atoms of the tetrahedral {M(C2O4)4}4- units and the M2+ metal ions. Considering that these oxygen atoms may also act as efficient hydrogen-bond acceptors, we have explored the possible construction of related hybrid architectures by assembling this anionic synthon with suitable organic cations through charge-assisted hydrogen bonds. Herein we report a series of networks formed from {Zr(C2O4)4}4- and dications bearing N−H donors. The selected organic dications (Chart 1) possess two hydrogen-donor units to allow them to bridge two {M(C2O4)4}4- units. The hydrogen linkage established between oxalate type complexes and a pyridinium functionality has been shown to be rather directional, the outer oxygen atoms of the oxalate unit binding to the H in very much the same manner as to a metal ion. Dipyridinium cations appeared therefore perfectly suited for our purpose, but amine derivatives have been investigated as well, some offering several hydrogen atoms for bonding. Finally, we have also envisaged the possibility to protonate the anion and associate it to a neutral organic unit with good hydrogen-acceptor capability but with poor base properties, i.e., bipyridine N-oxide. Depending on the nature of the donor group, the geometric features, and the sizes of the organic modules diverse assembling patterns have been observed ranging from one-dimensional (1-D) to 3-D networks.

<fig id="cg0609051c00001" position="float">
<label></label>
<graphic xlink:href="cg-2006-00905+_0002.tif"></graphic>
</fig>

The synthesis of the hybrid compounds described here have all been performed by mixing an acidic aqueous solution (pH = 2−4) of the organic module with a solution of K/Na4{Zr(C2O4)4} in a 2:1 ratio. Crystalline samples were obtained either by slow interdiffusion of the reagent solutions or by recrystallization of the formed solid. The different compounds thus prepared were characterized by single-crystal X-ray diffraction and chemical analyses. The [(H2amine)2{Zr(C2O4)4] networks show hydrogen interactions involving the oxalate and the ammonium/pyridinium moieties. The structurally most significant hydrogen bonds arise mainly from N−H···O interactions with N···O distances around 2.5 Å and N−H···O bond angles larger than 140°, in agreement with values observed for other {amine−H···oxalate} linkages. In the following, only the short hydrogen bonds (≤2.1 Å) have been considered to describe the formed architectures. We describe first the assemblage obtained with pyridinium cations, then the ammonium derivatives, and finally the surprising hybrid system realized with 4,4‘-bipyridine-N,N‘-dioxide. While this work was underway, the molecular structure for the 4,4‘-bipy derivative 1a has been reported. However, the synthetic approach that led to this compound is different from the one followed in this study, and its supramolecular organization was not described.
elements.clean_text:
Results and Discussion

The synthesis of the hybrid compounds described here have all been performed by mixing an acidic aqueous solution (pH = 2-4) of the organic module with a solution of K/Na4{Zr(C2O4)4} in a 2:1 ratio. Crystalline samples were obtained either by slow interdiffusion of the reagent solutions or by recrystallization of the formed solid. The different compounds thus prepared were characterized by single-crystal X-ray diffraction and chemical analyses. The [(H2amine)2{Zr(C2O4)4] networks show hydrogen interactions involving the oxalate and the ammonium/pyridinium moieties. The structurally most significant hydrogen bonds arise mainly from N-H⋅⋅⋅O interactions with N⋅⋅⋅O distances around 2.5 Å and N-H⋅⋅⋅O bond angles larger than 140°, in agreement with values observed for other {amine-H⋅⋅⋅oxalate} linkages. In the following, only the short hydrogen bonds (≤2.1 Å) have been considered to describe the formed architectures. We describe first the assemblage obtained with pyridinium cations, then the ammonium derivatives, and finally the surprising hybrid system realized with 4,4‘-bipyridine-N,N‘-dioxide. While this work was underway, the molecular structure for the 4,4‘-bipy derivative 1a has been reported. However, the synthetic approach that led to this compound is different from the one followed in this study, and its supramolecular organization was not described.

elements.content: [(H 2 Bipy) 2 {Zr(C 2 O 4 ) 4 ] (1a). The most simple dipyridine that has been considered is 4,4‘-bipyridine. The assembling process between {Zr(C2O4)4}4- and bipyridinium dications leads to an extended network were each inorganic {Zr(C2O4)4}4- unit is linked to four dipyridinium dications, and each organic cation is connected to two anion units. A strong charge-assisted hydrogen bond is established between one outer oxygen atom of each oxalate and a pyridinium moiety (O1···N6, 2.659(9) Å; O1−H2, 1.89 Å and O6···N1, 2.666(9) Å; O6−H1, 1.69 Å) from the dication (Figure ).

elements.content: The same linkage of the second pyridinium moiety to a second anionic unit develops a bidimensional (4,4) network. This grid frames large apertures of ca. 19 × 33 Å (see Figure ), but the available space is occupied by two identical networks that grow through the meshing of the first. The overall structure can be described as three interwoven parallel networks forming a layer (Figure c,d), the crystal lattice consisting of superposed layers. The plane of the pyridinium units are almost parallel to each other and adopt a slipped stacking. The distance of the stacked units in a layer is 3.47 Å (mean distances between the ring atoms and the mean plane of the adjacent pyridinium) and 3.33 Å between the layers (see Supporting Information), which support the occurrence of van der Waals π−π interactions between the pyridinium rings.

elements.content: [(H 2 BipyEthane) 2 {Zr(C 2 O 4 ) 4 }]·2H 2 O (1b). Assembling {Zr(C2O4)4}4- with protonated 1,2-di(4-pyridyl)ethane (b) also generates an extended network where each anionic building unit has hydrogen-bond linkages with four pyridinium moieties. These however involve only two of the four oxalate units and take place with two outer and two inner O atoms (O5B···N2, 2.75(4) Å; O5B···H3, 1.93(3) Å and O3···N1, 2.84(7) Å; O3···H8, 2.11(5) Å) as depicted in Figure .

elements.content: Each organic dication bridges symmetrically two {Zr(C2O4)4} units developing thus a two-dimensional (2-D) network with a factory-roof topology. Like for compound 1a, the [(H2BipyEthane)2{Zr(C2O4)4}] network frames rectangular windows with an 18 × 22 Å opening. The large dimension of these apertures allows four other [(H2BipyEthane)2{Zr(C2O4)4}] networks to grow through, and these 5-fold interpenetrated parallel nets are entangled into a 3-D structure (Figure c). No close contacts are found between the pyridinium units nor a stacking or T-shaped organization, which precludes significant π-interactions among them. The crystal structure revealed some space between the interlocked framework which is occupied by H2O molecules.

elements.content: [(H 2 BipyEthylene) 2 {Zr(C 2 O 4 ) 4 }]·4H 2 O (1c). Using di(4-pyridyl)ethylene (c) instead of di(4-pyridyl)ethane yields a different supramolecular organization. The hydrogen bonds established between the inorganic {Zr(C2O4)4}4- unit and H2BipyEthylene cations involve all four oxalate moieties through either an outer or an inner O atom. For one side of the cationic module the linkage is realized by means of a H2O. The resulting net develops along a single direction (Figure ) forming a zigzag chain in which the di(4-pyridyl)ethylene units stack pairwise in parallel. All nets run along the b-axes with two further H2O per formula unit located between them.

elements.content: Net developed by [(H2BipyEthylene)2{Zr(C2O4)4}] (1c). Selected distances:  N1···O1, 2.71(1) Å; H1···O1, 1.81(3) Å; N2···O30, 2.74(1) Å; H2···O30, 1.88(3) Å; O30···O6, 2.89(3)Å; H40···O6, 2.01(4) Å.

It was rather unexpected that the small chemical modification that consists of replacing a C−C single bond between the pyridine rings by a double bond would have such an effect on the assemblage obtained. A rationale for the formed organization might be found in the geometry of the organic units. The bipy-ethylene unit in 1c is perfectly planar as a result of the conjugation of the pyridine and ethylene π-systems, whereas such a conjugation does not exist for bipy-ethane. For the latter, the two pyridine rings in 1b are not coplanar. As a consequence the steric demand but also the secondary binding forces involved in the cohesion of the supramolecular network such as the π−π interactions between the aromatic moieties is different for the two organic cations leading to different supramolecular organizations. For 1c the two di(4-pyridyl)ethylene that link two anionic units are parallel but slipped in such a fashion that the ethylene moiety faces a pyridine ring (Figure ). The distances between facing atoms are 3.35−3.45 Å, suggesting the existence of substantial π−π interactions among the di(4-pyridyl)ethylene pairs. We have pointed out above that the geometric features for 1b do not support such π-interactions.

elements.content: As anticipated for this series of pyridine derivatives (a−c), the hydrogen-bonding scheme involves the outer oxygens of the oxalate units, but this is not exclusive and interactions with inner O atoms have been observed. To favor linkages with only the external O atoms of the oxalate, and ideally with the two available, we have envisaged to use organic cations with multi-hydrogen donor sites. An example of such a cationic building unit is the bis-amidinium derivative d.

elements.content: [(H 2 BisAmidine) 2 {Zr(C 2 O 4 ) 4 }] (1d). The architecture developed with cation d and {Zr(C2O4)4}4- consists of a 2-D network with an overall organization very much reminiscent of the structure of compound 1a. The building units are associated with hydrogen bonds established between the external O atoms and the amidinium hydrogen atoms (Figure ). However, the link is realized with only one of the four available hydrogen atoms for each donor site (O4···H2A, 2.07(5) Å; N2···O4, 2.81(2) Å, and O7···H3B, 2.02(4) Å; N3···O7, 2.833(3) Å). Despite a favorable positioning, the second is too long to be considered as a significant bond (O3···H1B, 2.28(4) Å; N1···O3, 2.944(4) Å; O8···H4B, 2.20(3) Å; N4···O8, 2.954(3) Å). Each [(H2BisAmidine)2{Zr(C2O4)4}] net is interlocked with two identical parallel nets to form layers similar to compound 1a, the overall crystal organization consisting of a lamellar structure of stacked layers. Rather short distances (3.39−3.41 Å) are found between the parallel but slipped bisamidinium units of adjacent layers (Supporting Information). The very similar architectures obtained with the 4,4‘-bipyridinium cation (a) and p-(bisamidinium)benzene (d) can be attributed to the very close features of these two molecules. They are planar and linear units of almost identical size; the intramolecular distance between the two hydrogen-atoms involved in the bonding to the anions is 8.83 Å for a and 8.91 Å for d.

elements.content: [( m -H 2 PhenDiamine) 2 {Zr(C 2 O 4 ) 4 }] · 2H 2 O (1e) and [( p -H 2 PhenDiamine) 2 {Zr(C 2 O 4 ) 4 }] · 4H 2 O (1f). Further examples of organic cations able to lead to multiple hydrogen bonding with the anionic unit are protonated phenylene diamine cations. These possess six acidic hydrogen atoms. The organization resulting from the assembling of the m-phenylene diammonium, (e) and {Zr(C2O4)4}4- is depicted in Figure . Each cationic unit is hydrogen-bonded to either three (donor {N3−N4}) or five (donor {N1−N2}) oxalate moieties, and each {Zr(C2O4)4}4- is linked to seven NH3 moieties from six different cations (for a detailed view see Supporting Information) developing a 3-D network. Two cationic and two anionic units are linked through four hydrogen bonds through N3 and N4 in a ring arrangement (Figure , top). Each ring is linked to the related rings located above and below by hydrogen bonds involving the N3 donors (N3···O16, 2.72(1) Å, H3C···O16, 2.11 Å) developing tubelike arrangements that are interconnected into a 3-D framework by linkages with the cation units {N1−N2} (Figure , bottom). The H2O molecules are located in the space within and between the tubes (Figure SI5, Supporting Information). In this network the organic cation is bridging the anionic units through linkages by its two donor moieties (N,N‘), by a single NH3 (N,N), and by a bifurcated hydrogen bond involving a single hydrogen atom linked to two acceptor units.

Each cationic unit is hydrogen-bonded to either three (donor {N3-N4}) or five (donor {N1-N2}) oxalate moieties, and each {Zr(C2O4)4}4- is linked to seven NH3 moieties from six different cations (for a detailed view see Supporting Information) developing a 3-D network. Two cationic and two anionic units are linked through four hydrogen bonds through N3 and N4 in a ring arrangement (Figure , top). Each ring is linked to the related rings located above and below by hydrogen bonds involving the N3 donors (N3⋅⋅⋅O16, 2.72(1) Å, H3C⋅⋅⋅O16, 2.11 Å) developing tubelike arrangements that are interconnected into a 3-D framework by linkages with the cation units {N1-N2} (Figure , bottom). The H2O molecules are located in the space within and between the tubes (Figure SI5, Supporting Information). In this network the organic cation is bridging the anionic units through linkages by its two donor moieties (N,N‘), by a single NH3 (N,N), and by a bifurcated hydrogen bond involving a single hydrogen atom linked to two acceptor units.

elements.content: Similarly, for the p-phenylene diamine derivative (f) the NH3 donor groups are involved in several hydrogen linkages. A view of the connections established between the cations and the anionic units in [(p-H2PhenDiamine)2{Zr(C2O4)4}]·4H2O (1f) is given in Figure . Each {Zr(C2O4)4}4- is linked to four organic cations, but only one of the two cations acts as a bridge between anionic units. Two organic units are hydrogen-bonded to two {Zr(C2O4)4} by means of their donor units N3 and N4 (Figure , top), the latter N4 moieties being further linked to the oxalates of a related primary assemblage hence developing a 2-D network (Figure , bottom). The nonbridging cations are linked to one anionic unit by ammonium N1, the second being involved in a hydrogen bond with the H2O located between the layers. The space existing within the network and between the layers is occupied by H2O molecules hydrogen-bonded to the framework (see Supporting Information).

elements.content: [(H 2 Piperazine) 2 {Zr(C 2 O 4 ) 4 }]·1H 2 O (1g). The last dication investigated is the diprotonated piperazine (g) that presents potentially two NH2 donor groups for hydrogen linkages to the anionic {Zr(C2O4)4}4-. The crystal structure for [(H2Piperazine)2{Zr(C2O4)4}]·1H2O (1g) reveals that whereas the two cations form hydrogen bonds with the {Zr(C2O4)4}4- units only one acts as a N,N‘-bridge thus developing a 1-D network (Figure ). Some of the remaining NH are well positioned to link the chain together; however, the distances to the oxalates O atoms are somewhat long to be considered as substantial hydrogen bonds (H4A···O15, 2.114(6) Å; H4A···O16, 2.22 (1) Å; H3A···O11, 2.182(6) Å). Related interchain hydrogen bonds are found with the other piperazine units (H2A···02, 2.164(8) Å; H1B···O7, 2.224(7) Å; H1B···O8, 2.15(1) Å). A view of the 3-D network developed with these weaker interactions is provided as Supporting Information.

elements.content: [K{(bipyO) 2 H}{Zr(C 2 O 4 ) 4 }(H 3 O) 2 ] (1h). The presence of the oxygen linked to the pyridine nitrogen atom dramatically reduces the basic character of pyridine-N-oxides, but very localized charges (N+−O-) render the O atom a strong hydrogen-bond acceptor. We have envisaged to use such a pyridine oxide to reverse the hydrogen-donor/hydrogen-acceptor roles that applied so far, that is, to have a protonated {Zr(C2O4)4H x }(4- x )- acting as inorganic hydrogen donor unit and the organic counterpart playing the role of hydrogen acceptor. This attempt was made with 4,4‘-dipyridine-N-oxide (h) as a potential hydrogen-acceptor because of its structural similarity with 4,4‘-bipyridine. Assembling indeed takes place, but the resulting supramolecular architecture is significantly different from that of 1a and exhibits some peculiar features. For the first time, potassium is found in the developed framework. Each {Zr(C2O4)4} unit is connected to four K+ ions, and each K is linked to four Zr units developing a 2-D coordination polymer (Figure , top). The coordination sphere of the K consists of six O atoms of four oxalate moieties, two chelating and two monodentate, and two oxygen of two bipyO positioned in trans, i.e., above and below the {Zr−C2O4−K} layers. Interconnection between the inorganic layers and the bipyO units is achieved by hydrogen-bonding by the means of H3O+ units (Figure , middle) that are linked by two H to oxalate oxygens (O4···H33 and O7···H34) and the third forming a rather strong hydrogen bond with bipyO (O9···H35). A further hydrogen linkage is also found for the second NO moiety of the bipyO units. Here, a H+ is connected to two N-oxides oxygen atoms (O10) from two bipyO units. Such a rather striking diadduct of pyridine-N-oxides sharing a proton has been observed before. The overall architecture of [K{(bipyO)2H}{Zr(C2O4)4}(H3O)2] (1h) can be described as inorganic layers of [K{Zr(C2O4)4] coordination polymers with intercalated organic bipyO units acting as pillars (Figure , bottom). For this compound, both the organic bipyO and the inorganic {Zr(C2O4)4}4- units act as hydrogen-acceptors, and the actual hydrogen-bond donors are H3O+ molecules. The stronger hydrogen-bond acceptor is clearly the bipyO with a much shorter linkage to H3O+ as compared to oxalate O atoms (for bond distances see caption to Figure ). This is also reflected by the lengthening of the concerned covalent H−O bond in H3O+. An even shorter hydrogen-bond is observed with the proton found between two pyridine-oxide units (O10). The O10···O10 separation (2.44 Å) in 1h well fits with the O···O distance (2.39 Å) for which it has been shown that the proton is symmetrically “shared” by the two O atoms.

elements.content: The hybrid supramolecular architectures 1a−1f formed by charge-assisted hydrogen-bonding underline several interesting points. Most surprising is that the hydrogen bonds to the oxalates take place not only with the outer oxygen atoms but also involve the inner ones. This was unexpected as the latter correspond to the first coordination sphere of the Zr that is rather crowded. The only hydrogen-donor group for which inner hydrogen-interaction was not observed is the amidinium (derivative d). This group has actually two donor sites (H2N−C−NH2) well positioned to interact with the two outer O of an oxalate. This could be a directing parameter even if a non-symmetrical interaction is found in 1d with a short and much longer hydrogen bond. The fact that the hydrogen-bonded network does not develop in the continuation of the Zr-oxalate directions is not surprising because of the versatile geometry of the hydrogen-bond interaction; moreover, the linkage to the inner oxalate oxygens also contribute to this. A further less obvious reason is the deformation of the coordination sphere of the {Zr(C2O4)4} units. For instance, for 1a, although the hydrogen linkages with the organic cations are established with the outer O atoms of the four oxalates, and therefore in the three directions of space, the network extends only in 2-D. The {Zr(C2O4)4} units in 1a exhibit a rather strong distortion with their central metal ion no longer located in the plane of the oxalate ligand. As a result, the bipyridinium units can align in a plane as shown in Figure d, a situation that favors π-interactions between the layers, which could be the reason for this preferred organization. A comparison of the {Zr(C2O4)4} units in 1a−h and in K4{Zr(C2O4)4} illustrating the flexibility of the anionic core is given in Figure . The deformation occurring for each of compounds 1a−1h is clearly evidenced by the polyhedron of tetrahedral shape defined by the midpoint between the external oxygen atoms of the four oxalate moieties.

elements.content: Thermal Stability. The thermal stability of the hybrid architectures have been evaluated by thermogravimetric analysis (TGA). The behavior obtained for [(H2BipyEthylene)2{Zr(C2O4)4}]·4H2O (1c) is depicted in Figure . The H2O molecules contained by the framework are released in mild conditions, but the chemical scaffold associating the inorganic and organic building units is stable up to ca. 300 °C. Two types of H2O molecules occur for compound 1c, two H2O are lattice molecules and two are part of the framework. Their release occurs at slightly different temperatures (inset Figure ) in agreement with different binding energies to the solid, but all four H2O are removed at 120 °C. Above 300 °C, the hybrid solid rapidly loses its organic components as well as the oxalate to yield above 550 °C a sample mass corresponding to ZrO2. The thermal behavior of 1c represents a typical example of the behavior of the compounds involving pyridinium donor units. Surprisingly, [(p-H2PhenDiamine)2{Zr(C2O4)4}]·4H2O (1f) appeared to be much more sensitive to thermal decomposition. Whereas H2O release is observed as anticipated below 100 °C, the hybrid architecture loses its organic components above 140 °C (see Supporting Information). The thermal stability of the piperazinium-based network 1g was found to be very similar to those of the pyridinium derivative with a hybrid framework stable to 300 °C.

elements.content: The aim of this study was to explore the possibility to construct extended hybrid hydrogen-bonded networks by association of an anionic coordination complex and organic cations acting respectively as hydrogen-bond acceptor and hydrogen-bond donors. The series of simple bis-functional cations revealed that the resulting association scheme strongly depends on the nature of the hydrogen-donor group and the number of hydrogen atoms available for bonding. The pyridinium hydrogen-donor group appears to be the most predictable because of the single connection it can establish with the oxalate moiety even if this interaction may occur with the outer or inner O atoms of the hydrogen-acceptor. In this respect the amidinium cation has preferred interaction with the outer oxygens. Donor groups with two or three available hydrogen atoms were thought to reinforce the bonding strength between the building units, but they appeared to lead to unpredictable and rather compact assemblages. Finally, with pyridine-oxide both the NO function and the oxalate units act as hydrogen-acceptor moieties. This allows characterization of a 3-D network that contains H3O+ and H+ units stabilized by hydrogen bonds with the framework.
elements.clean_text:
Concluding Remarks

The aim of this study was to explore the possibility to construct extended hybrid hydrogen-bonded networks by association of an anionic coordination complex and organic cations acting respectively as hydrogen-bond acceptor and hydrogen-bond donors. The series of simple bis-functional cations revealed that the resulting association scheme strongly depends on the nature of the hydrogen-donor group and the number of hydrogen atoms available for bonding. The pyridinium hydrogen-donor group appears to be the most predictable because of the single  connection it can establish with the oxalate moiety even if this interaction may occur with the outer or inner O atoms of the hydrogen-acceptor. In this respect the amidinium cation has preferred interaction with the outer oxygens. Donor groups with two or three available hydrogen atoms were thought to reinforce the bonding strength between the building units, but they appeared to lead to unpredictable and rather compact assemblages. Finally, with pyridine-oxide both the NO function and the oxalate units act as hydrogen-acceptor moieties. This allows characterization of a 3-D network that contains H3O+ and H+ units stabilized by hydrogen bonds with the framework.

elements.content: General. All chemicals obtained by commercial route were used as received for synthesis. Na4{Zr(C2O4)4}, K4{Zr(C2O4)4}, and the terephtalamidine d have been prepared according to the literature methods. Deionized H2O obtained over ion exchanger resins was used for all preparations. Thermogravimetric analysis have been performed in air with a heating rate of 1 °C/min between 20 and 120 °C and 5 °C/min above 120 °C on a CETARAM 98.16.18 apparatus. The IR spectra were collected from KBr pellet with a Perkin-Elmer Spectrum GX or Paragon 1000 spectrophotometer in the range 4000−400 cm-1.

Experimental Section

 General. All chemicals obtained by commercial route were used as received for synthesis. Na4{Zr(C2O4)4}, K4{Zr(C2O4)4}, and the terephtalamidine d  have been prepared according to the literature methods. Deionized H2O obtained over ion exchanger resins was used for all preparations. Thermogravimetric analysis have been performed in air with a heating rate of 1 °C/min between 20 and 120 °C and 5 °C/min above 120 °C on a CETARAM 98.16.18 apparatus. elements.content: Crystallographic Studies. For all compounds except 1c the single-crystal diffraction data have been collected on a Nonius Kappa CCD diffractometer at 298 K using Mo Kα graphite monochromated radiation (λ(MoK α) = 0.71069 Å). For 1c intensity data was obtained from an XCALIBUR Oxford CCD diffractometer using a MoKα radiation (0.71073 Å) at 180 K. For all compounds the structure was solved by direct methods using the program SHELXS-97; the refinement and all further calculations were carried out using SHELXL-97. Empirical absorption corrections were applied in all cases with SCALEPACK. The non-H atoms were refined anisotropically, using weighted full-matrix least-squares on F2. Crystallographic data are summarized in Table . The hydrogen atoms were computed in the final refinement model with isotropic temperature factors of the linked atoms, whereas non-hydrogen atoms were refined with anisotropic thermal parameters. For 1a, 1e, and 1f, hydrogen atoms were introduced in idealized positions and refined with a riding model. For the rest the hydrogen atoms have been placed experimentally. Some disorder has been observed for structures 1c, 1e, and 1h. In 1c, this concerns the noncoordinated oxygens of the oxalates for which two equivalent positions are observed. Two distinct positions with an occupational factor of 0.5 are used for each external oxygen of the oxalates. For structure 1e, a position close to the edge of the unit cell is attributed to a water molecule (O10), with an occupational factor of 0.5. A very short distance between the two water molecules resulting from the symmetry operation is observed. Finally, in compound 1h two distinct positions are also observed for the oxygen of the N-oxybipyridine and the oxygen of the hydroxonium.

cln_elements.content: Thermal Stability. The thermal stability of the hybrid architectures have been evaluated by thermogravimetric analysis (TGA). The behavior obtained for [(H2BipyEthylene)2{Zr(C2O4)4}]·4H2O (1c) is depicted in Figure . The H2O molecules contained by the framework are released in mild conditions, but the chemical scaffold associating the inorganic and organic building units is stable up to ca. 300 °C. Two types of H2O molecules occur for compound 1c, two H2O are lattice molecules and two are part of the framework. Their release occurs at slightly different temperatures (inset Figure ) in agreement with different binding energies to the solid, but all four H2O are removed at 120 °C. Above 300 °C, the hybrid solid rapidly loses its organic components as well as the oxalate to yield above 550 °C a sample mass corresponding to ZrO2. The thermal behavior of 1c represents a typical example of the behavior of the compounds involving pyridinium donor units. Surprisingly, [(p-H2PhenDiamine)2{Zr(C2O4)4}]·4H2O (1f) appeared to be much more sensitive to thermal decomposition. Whereas H2O release is observed as anticipated below 100 °C, the hybrid architecture loses its organic components above 140 °C (see Supporting Information). The thermal stability of the piperazinium-based network 1g was found to be very similar to those of the pyridinium derivative with a hybrid framework stable to 300 °C.
